Award.AwardTitle: Treeable Equivalence Relations and the Use of Probability Groups in Arithmetic Combinatorics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a research project at the interface of the mathematical topics of set theory, combinatorics, and analysis. The research contains three projects involving two main areas of mathematics: descriptive set theory and ergodic Ramsey theory. The first two of the research projects lie in the theory of definable equivalence relations, which provides a general framework for understanding the nature of classification of mathematical objects up to some notion of equivalence; due to its broad scope, it has natural interactions with many areas of mathematics. These two projects are devoted to studying an important subclass of definable equivalence relations and whether slight extensions of the members of this subclass still belong to it. The third project features a new method for obtaining statements in arithmetic combinatorics similar in nature to a celebrated theorem of Szemeredi, which roughly states that any non-negligible subset of integers retains much of the additive structure of the entire set of integers.

In the theory of definable equivalence relations on Polish spaces, a central place is occupied by countable Borel equivalence relations, an important subclass of which is that of treeable equivalence relations. The first two projects investigate the question of closure of this subclass under finite index extensions in two different contexts: Borel and measure-theoretic. The former involves Borel combinatorics and possibly Borel games, whereas the latter is tightly connected with ergodic theory and the theory of cost of equivalence relations, and may require nontrivial machinery from geometric group theory. The third project lies in ergodic Ramsey theory and its goal is to obtain multiple recurrence results for amenable groups via a correspondence principle provided by nonstandard analysis. This is done by transferring recurrence statements from a given amenable group to a more convenient setting of probability groups by taking the ultrapower of the original group and equipping it with Loeb measure. The latter, being countably additive, presents the main advantage of the probability group over the original amenable group equipped with only a finitely additive density function, enabling integration over the group and the use of Fubini's theorem.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The proposal comprised two projects within different subjects. 

Countable Borel equivalence relations, treeings, and ergodicity. The first and main project lay in the study of countable Borel equivalence relations (CBERs) in the Borel and measurable contexts. These naturally appear as the orbit equivalence relations of Borel actions of countable groups. From another, rather combinatorial, angle, CBERs can always be viewed as the connectedness relations of locally countable Borel graphs (graphings). These strong connections between equivalence relations, group actions, and graphs create an extremely fruitful interplay between descriptive set theory, ergodic theory, measured group theory, probability, descriptive graph combinatorics, and geometric group theory.

The project was mainly focusing on the treeable CBERs, i.e., those that admit an acyclic graphing. Towards understanding constructions of trees from geometric group theory, the PI gave a streamlined proof of Stallings' well-known theorem on ends of groups, which the PI adapted further to Borel graphs, obtaining a sufficient condition for treeability of CBERs. In the vein of treeability, the PI's and B. Miller jointly proved a graph decomposition theorem, which, combined with an ergodic theorem for probability measure preserving (pmp) graphs of R. Tucker-Drob, yields an ergodic-theoretic strengthening of G. Hjorth's theorem on cost attained for treeable pmp CBERs.

Developing further tools for dealing with measurable graphs, the PI established a pointwise ergodic theorem for quasi-pmp (nonsingular) Borel graphs, which generalizes R. Tucker-Drob's theorem for pmp graphs mentioned above. This theorem is, in a way, the best possible ergodic statement for the Schreier graphs of quasi-pmp actions of certain groups, like the free groups, because the classical version of the pointwise ergodic theorem fails for such actions, as shown by M. Hochman.

Ultraproducts and combinatorics. The theme of the second project was to prove results in additive and extremal combinatorics using the methods and ideology of logic such as tools from model theory and nonstandard analysis (ultraproducts).

Additive combinatorics largely concerns the phenomenon of multiple recurrence (reoccurring patterns) in semigroups. The PI introduced the class of probability groups and developed the basics of their pmp actions. This yielded a short and simple proof of a generalization of the main result of V. Bergelson and T. Tao on double recurrence for quasirandom groups.

An active line of research in extremal combinatorics is extending classical results from the dense setting (e.g. Szemerédi's theorem) to the sparse random setting. These results state that a property of a given “dense” structure is inherited by a randomly chosen “sparse” substructure. A recent breakthrough tool for proving such statements is the Balogh–Morris–Samotij and Saxton–Thomason hypergraph containers method, which bounds the number of independent sets in finite hypergraphs. Jointly with A. Bernshteyn, M. Delcourt, and H. Towsner, the PI gave a new – elementary and nonalgorithmic – proof of the containers theorem for finite hypergraphs. This proof was inspired by considering the ultraproduct of hypergraphs, where there is a notion of dimension capturing the logarithmic rate of growth of finite sets. Applying this intuition in another setting with a notion of dimension, namely, algebraically closed fields, and using tools from model theory, A. Bernshteyn, M. Delcourt, and the PI proved an analogous theorem for "dense" algebraically definable hypergraphs.

Broader impact. In the duration of the support, the PI has been supervising two PhD and one Master's student. One of her PhD students, Anton Bernshteyn (now a postdoc at Carnegie Mellon University), graduated in May 2018 with an extremely strong and broad PhD thesis in Borel and measurable combinatorics, ergodic theory, and finite combinatorics. The PI's Master's student, Wei Dai, also graduated in May 2018 and has started a PhD at CMU.

Dissemination of results. During the grant period, the PI gave 20 invited talks (3 of which plenary) at various conferences/workshops, whose subject areas included set theory, descriptive set theory, ergodic theory, operator algebras, analysis, general logic, combinatorics, nonstandard analysis, and Ramsey theory. She also gave 5 colloquium talks and was an invited participant in long-term research programs at the Institut Mittag-Leffler in Sweden and at the Bernoulli Center in Switzerland.
